Topic.Title: IPod

Message.Msg: "Why would someone want a $300 4 inch iPod" Actually it is the same price as the older 32gb iPod Touch (the old ipod touch entry level 8gb is $199 though) Anyway, I think this could effectively be positioned as a competent replacement for a mid-priced point & shoot cameras which are also priced in that range. Only thing missing is an optical zoom. But then you get all the other goodies!

Message.Title: NTWK $5.6, a global cloud software provider, has been inching up daily after monster 4Q and FY 2012 earnings and guidance calling for an additional 30 - 40% revenue growth and $1/share net income in 2013……. Analysts upped NTWK's average target price to $16/share with a $21/share max…….Currently trading at a 5.5 forward P/E and 1 times sales…3M share float.....I expect an eventual explosion to $10+ in the short term.
Message.Msg: SHORT TERM TARGET: $10 Because of exponential growth of its existing Cloud Division Vroozi and the announcement of a separate Cloud Division last week, NTWK expects revenues and Net Income to Double/Triple by 2015. A few more NTWK Highlights: - Chart shows $10 in the near term with technicals improving daily. - Cloud division Vroozi reported 1000% increase in revenues Q/Q in 4Q 2013. Explosive growth expected for 2013 and beyond - Announced 2nd Cloud Division last week - Company projects Doubling/Tripling revenues and net income by 2015 - Significant Institutional investor ownership and growing - Insiders bought over 5% of the Outstanding shares the last 2 years and never sold a single share - Total share count is only 7.5 million shares. The float is only 3 million shares - Trading at forward PE of 5 - Strong balance sheet with $1.5/share cash - Has global agreement with Mercedes Benz - Already 7 countries with NTWK software for leasing and financing Mercedes Benz/Daimler including China, India, Japan, and others - No.1 in China and APAC in leasing/financing software products and services. NTWK has over 50 Fortune 100 loyal customers. Never lost a customer. None of the customers is over 5% of the total revenues - partial customer list: CitiGroup, Mercedes Benz, Santander, BMW, Volvo, Ford, GE Capital, Cisco Capital, Paribas, GMAC, Volvo, Toyota, Nissan, Hyundai, BYD, SANY Corp. China, etc. About NTWK: NetSol Technologies, Inc. ((NASDAQ: NTWK) is a worldwide provider of global IT and enterprise application solutions that include credit and finance portfolio management systems, SAP consulting and services, custom development, systems integration, and technical services for the global Financial, Leasing, Insurance, Energy, and Technology markets. Headquartered in Calabasas, Calif., NetSol's product and services offerings have achieved ISO 9001, ISO 20000, ISO 27001, and SEI (Software Engineering Institute) CMMI (Capability Maturity Model) Maturity Level 5 assessments, a distinction shared by only 178 companies worldwide. The company's clients include Fortune 500 manufacturers, global automakers, financial institutions, utilities, technology providers, and government agencies. NetSol has delivery and support locations in San Francisco, London, Beijing, Bangkok, Lahore, Adelaide and Riyadh.

Message.Title: Will Amazon Buy Interdigital for its Patents?
Message.Msg: To protect its LTE Tablet computer ? IDCC seems like a logical place for Amazon to pick up a nice chunk of the limited 3G, 4G, and LTE patent pool. Interdigital isnt the only company with patents. But they do have a variety patents. Some of the remaining ones might be useful to amazon. IDCC has told the market they are getting ready to sell another batch of non core patents in the near future. Idcc has several notebook manufacturers licensed, and also boasts some M2M patents, and these are the kind of things a company like amazon would probably be interested in. Maybe Amazon is bidding on the next batch and IDCC has told us several groups are interested in major batch 2. And once major batch 2 goes, the company will have jettisoned about 25% of their patents. IDCC has told us during the failed company sale, several companies were interested in groups of patents, but not everything. After batch 2 goes, it more likely a big player might be interested in buying IDCC and the remaining core business. Adding patents would help Amazon protect itself against lawsuits alleging illegal use of technology. Amazon has been involved in five patent-related cases this year, and 20 cases last year, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Demand for mobile patents has increased, as shown recently by Google’s $12.5 billion acquisition of Motorola Mobility Holdings Inc. and its thousands of patents, which closed this year. I bet IDCC would accept $75-$80/share. The company has a huge short interest about 14% of share float and is near to breaking out the 36 resistance level. We could a huge squeeze on Interdigital today or next week, so keep it in your screens !!! The stock could skyrocket !

The company builds tools that enable users to connect, share, discover, and communicate with each other; enables developers to build social applications on Facebook or to integrate their Websites with Facebook; and offers products that enable advertisers and marketers to engage with its users. Topic.Title: IPod

Message.Msg: "Thanks for pointing out that the Fire has an HDMI connection. Not a great solution, but I did forget." It's a "good enough" solution for the time being for millions of consumers nevertheless who do not wish to be locked into Apple's closed system. I used to bring along my ipod and use it for some personal things and work related things too to play video from and show photos, you used to be able to run a slideshow onto a large TV monitor with just the most generic of cables that might be on-hand, already so no extra cost or prep or packing. I'd buy numerous third-party peripherals (Belkin and others, microphones, cables, etc.) since Apple was always too "minimalist" to focus on these kinds of things and Apple would constantly include changes in later software updates that would make peripherals once compatible worthless. I started building a library of iTunes movies only to find that Apple would keep cutting off my ability to use these peripherals. At first they'd work, but months later they would not. There's a reason Apple has high margins. They overcharge customers and as described above they're extremely aggressive in trying to bilk customers for not only their main products but also for many overpriced peripherals. "The Apple TV is currently a $99 module that is continuously being (software) upgraded." But why do you think everyone (millions apparently don't) wants to pay an extra toll to Apple? Apple is all about setting up numerous toll gates at each of which they bilk the passive consumer for more and more money. An iPad you buy for $1000 for (hardware plus connection plan) doesn't really cost $1000, it costs $1100 because you can't just use your cable that you already have, you have to go through the Apple toll gate and pay an extra $100 for some extraneous module. "Apple is working on other set top box ideas, but most of the rumors have proven untrue." It will fail. People are on to Apple, now. They don't want to pay Apple for all these extra things like modules. Suckers that do will probably find Apple will render the module un-usable after a couple of years ("we will stop supporting the module with updates starting next month...") so they can bilk customers for another $99. They have already stopped supporting the original iPad, for example. "I got stopped out of my short today" I don't know why you use stops. Techstrategy assured me that this stock is going way, way below $230 in a few months, guaranteed. He says his analysis has never lost and this implies that you should have doubled down at $260 instead.

Here, yesterday after the Fed infusion speak, I covered my 100 shares short and sold my $270 oct call and walked away. I figured that although AMZN is way overpriced, that a large wave can lift all boats, and 'it' did....lol. Also, I figured that the Ca tax may not be a bad thing, if AMZN figures out to lower prices along with that to compensate, especially if the shipping time is only one day. I don't like Bezos personally but he proves to be a smart one. And while I would not short here, it would still take strong nerves to hold here too! - Good luck!

Topic.Title: IPod

Message.Msg: "I didn't think Ben would be stupid enough to do it." Why not? You were stupid enough to short Amazon at $230 and to say Google would outperform but was only up 5% year-to-date as of last week. "when something goes wrong the crisis of confidence will be much worse if not irreparable." Or nothing goes that wrong at all and you get to bite the dust twice as badly as you already are. Or something goes wrong but the impact is nothing near as bad as the dismal shorts say it will be just as Google has performed much worse than you predicted. "But, it is also why I have been short mainly consumer/retail stories. The commodity/oil/gas inflation will hit the consumer hard and negate the Fed's money printing." Or the government gets more money by forcing Amazon to collect sales taxes, albeit at the state level and then pays it back out to consumers in the form of stimulus. This is a win for customers, an win for Amazon, a win for the government, a big fat punch in the gut to the shorts. "consumers simply do not calculate the fuel costs of driving to the store." Shorts have said this for years and it has made no difference. Obviously enough consumers do care about spending on fuel these days. But this is also connected to your next point... "Amazon, pays for the "last mile". Gas price increases favor Costco, WalMart and Target which service a broad array of consumer needs." So why is it that with every spike in fuel prices in the past Amazon's business results and share price always far outperformed those retailers and shorts got wiped out?

Topic.Title: IPod

Message.Msg: Nemesis: Like I said, I'll be here for the next year. We'll see if the scam holds until then... Shorting AMZN at $230 (via LT DITM puts by the way) was not stupid. It will prove to be a fantastic return. Sure. Or nothing goes wrong. Cannot imagine what could possibly go wrong while wages are stagnant and necessities shoot through the roof... It all depends upon one's time horizon. I'm sticking with my long GOOG short AMZN investment. No question in my mind that it will pay off handsomely. Amazon had a tax subsidy in the past that effectively gave it 5-10% towards the incremental transportation cost. It doesn't have that now. And, when fuel prices increase, transportation cost become a larger share of the total, structurally disadvantaging AMZN. All good strategy and all good investing is content dependent. We are in a different time and place, but you'll learn that the hard way I suppose.

Message.Title: AMZN will close RED.
Message.Msg: It's most over valued stock. Its growth story will end soon, start losing money, then cut cost. Some big impact to its core business. * Sales Tax will affect its retail business quite badly. Many smaller e-tails still have the tax advantage for a while * Its Kindle Fire got negative review from many sites. Cannot compete with Google Nexus 7. * Apple and Google are seriously getting into digital products, movies, song, and e-books with their tablets. Amazon has no advantage at all in this area. * Oracle/IBM/HP are also getting into cloud computer business beside original Microsoft, Google, Apple and many other companies. Cloud Computer eventually will be compete on the price and applications. Amazon doesn't have the applications that can charge for high subscription fees.

Message.Title: The question Gillis should ask on the next conference call...
Message.Msg: I saw Gillis because he's the only remotely intellectually honest analyst. Mahaney is not remotely intellectually honest... Directed to Bezos: Specifically excluding product categories with new launches in the quarter (e.g. Kindle platform and concurrently purchased Prime Memberships), what were your average sales per day in California before Sept 15th and in the two weeks afterward? While is is possible if not likely that the numbers this quarter will mask the sales tax impact (particularly if stories of loading up before the end of the ST holiday are true, which would also explain the need to launch the Kindle prior to getting FCC approval for the 4G version), the event related change in sales intensity should prove enlightening...

Topic.Title: The question Gillis should ask on the next conference call...

Message.Msg: I'm very serious with my money. That's why I will see this through so that the impact of collecting sales tax on Amazon becomes clear. There would be no "stocking up" in advance of the sales tax deadline if it were not material. Besides, I kind of like watching Amazon go up against Apple and Google after years of bullying little mom and pop retailers who had to collect taxes. When the facts come out, the narrative of Amazon's success will change to the company that displaced hundreds of thousands, maybe millions, of retail workers and businesses all built upon a grand tax subsidy that it is now trying to end so it doesn't face the same asymmetric competitive landscape that propelled it here... Amazon has done a great job branding itself. If that brand position were to ever take a hit, the fallout would be huge..

Message.Title: Bernanke's REAL reason behind
Message.Msg: Bernanke knows QEs did not help hobs and will not help on jobs. The real and only reason behind the move is to secure HIS own job! Because he knows to make the policy as if it was aiming at improving job for Americans, it will help Obama's chance to get re-elected; nly if Obama gets re-elected, then he will have his own job security.. Period. I can tell you now, the only thing will get higher and STAY higher is the prices of your foods, fruits, fuel, vegetables, plus prices of clothes, and other things. At some point, even the middle class people will stop taking it, then you see more social conflicts and unrest.

Topic.Title: How many knuckleheaded dopes could possibly be left buying these levelz

Message.Msg: Ski: I'll always be here until reality sets in on this scam... Pretty soon, sales prior to tax collection in CA can be compared (ex-kindle/Prime launch) to the results for the rest of Sept. If anything, the rest of Sept should have Benny Boy's QE pump and should help... Yet, I bet (again, ex-Kindle and bundled Prime) sales per day will slow in the latter half of the month. Regardless, I'll be here to test my hypothesis and see if I am right. Looking forward to the Apple iPad announcements. I'll be surprised if Siri isn't running on the new iPads, which will differentiate them from other 7" tablets. A nice $249-$299 entry price and Apple will create pain for AMZN. It will be interesting to see if people are flocking to the Kindle (as pumpers would have you believe) or if they are waiting to see what Apple is going to do. I suspect more are doing the latter right now... There just really isn't a compelling reason to buy a tablet until the playing field is set for this year. Good luck pal...

Message.Title: Sold some at $260
Message.Msg: For some reason I can't post under my Harmonica Bruce ID, so I'm using my daughter's account. I some at $260, I paid $135 for it 3 years ago. I'll sell more at $300, or buy back if it drops a lot. What a stock! The stock I now own was free, I've sold enough to pay for all that I've bought and more. In other words, if AMZN goes to zero tomorrow, I'm up about $40 per share. So for all the shorts who told me I'll end up losing money on AMZN, to bad chumps!

Topic.Title: Sold some at $260

Message.Msg: Bruce: Given what you said, it would seem you must have sold more than "some" given that it has doubled from your purchase and you would still have a profit of $40 a share even if what you have left goes to zero (I've been spending a lot of time teaching my 7th grade daughters algebra for their class at New Trier and this will make for a good problem for them). $260 * x% + $0 (100-x%) = $135 + $40... Solve for X... Now for the serious part, congratulations. People like you are why I spent time posting fundamental and strategic analysis despite all the taunting from JA's lime Nemesis and Geeg. Just as getting out of GMCR north of $100 was a gift, so too getting out of AMZN north of $200 is a gift.
